Title: My Mother Dreams the Satan's Disciples in New York
Author: Rex Pickett

The two of them, Marian looking puzzled.
to Marian, her brow knitted thoughtfully in a schoolmarmish expression.
You forgot your fucking plant, you fucking asshole!

And there's a lot of other shit in there you forgot.  Just wait there, I'm going to go fucking get it for you, all right? No, just wait there! Do you want me to go get it for you?  Well, why don't I just do that, huh?  I'm going to do that right now!
stops dead in her tracks and stares in heartstopping terror.
in horror, cannot pry her eyes away from them.
standing in the window in her nightgown, a hand covering her mouth, looking down in utter terror on the fire-lit tableaux of her nightmare.
gasps, then blushes and quickly replaces the pictures.
draws away from the window.  She picks up her "Streetwise Manhattan" laminated map, puts her glasses on, looks at it, debating whether to tackle the streets of New York or not.
at the security door of Paula's building.  She rummages anxiously through her purse, but she can't find her keys!
turns away from the escalating violence across the street and punches one of the buttons on the intercom.  A WOMAN'S VOICE crackles over it.
sitting on the floor, propped against the door to their unit.
turns to the Head Disciple, materializing behind her, carrying her luggage.  He gestures with his head toward the motorcycles.

The BIKERS, wearing their club's colors embroidered on blue jeans, and leather, vests, back their motorcycles in a uniform row against the curb, kill their engines, park them at an angle on their kickstands, and dismount.
The Bikers continue to roughhouse the Kid.  The Disciple Prospect brandishes a plastic bag under his nose.
Mom!  Hi!  I'll be right down.
So, what do you think?
You don't like where I live?
That's New York.  It looks rundown, but it's safe during the day.  You'll get used to it.
Uh-huh?
That's the Satan's Disciples' New York headquarters.
I've never had any problem with them. People say it's the safest block in the East Village.
I just hope their motorcycles don't keep you up at night.
Replies.Didascalie: (lays a reassuring hand on her mother's arm)

The Disciples kick the drug-dealing Teenager a couple more times, then set him free, laughing as he flees down the block in mortal fear.
Marian drops the appropriate coins in the coin slot and dials a number from memory.
Marian walks quickly ACROSS THE FRAME.  As she EXITS RIGHT, the Disciple Prospect ENTERS LEFT and trails after her.
Marian is standing at the window looking down on the street.
Marian looking apprehensively down at the Disciples' headquarters, stupefied.

I'm sorry.  I had a wretched night.

Replies.Reply: Marian!
Marian's daughter lives across the street and she was a little worried about her.
You know, if we can do anything for you, Marian, you just let us know.
Well, we'll, uh, see what we can do, Marian.

They reach the main room where about ten or so DISCIPLES are lounging about.  One has his nose in a book, The Road Less Traveled.  Another reads the Wall Street Journal.  Two others are seated at a card table, playing a game of poker.  Still another is sprawled on a couch, smoking a cigarette.  The walls are festooned with biker posters.  The place is a bit of a mess, but innocuous.
Hi, Marian.
of overflowing ashtrays, crushed beer cans, fast food wrappers balled up and strewn on tables.
of several of the Disciples' FACES, turning to her in SLOW MOTION with mock baleful looks of disapprobation.
Thanks, Marian.
of idling Harleys in the middle of the street, waiting for her.
The Disciple Prospect takes Marian's luggage from the Head Disciple and hauls it over to one of the waiting Harleys and straps it on to the carrying rack.
